comments.commentBody:
Mark Thomason:

Sometime it jsut isn't "they all do it."

****
You're right. It is not this at all. It is the behavior of this particular president matched with this particular Congress. They are a match that has led to terribly dysfunctional politics.

The president's actions on immigration now have re-ignited the fire.

The level of competitiveness and single-mindedness that we expect from elite athletes would be considered pathological in most walks of life. Donovan has deviated ever so slightly from the script but still managed to play this physically demanding and grinding sport at the highest level for more than a decade. May his healthy perspective on things serve him well in his post-playing days.

Somewhere on YouTube there's a clip of U.S.-Germany from the 2002 World Cup with the U.S., mainly Donovan, marauding forward repeatedly, moving a startled British announcer to say, "Delightful soccer being played by the U.S." Donovan has played the beautiful game beautifully. When the U.S. produces someone better than him, well, it will really be something.

We used to have a great program for farm workers. It was called the Bracero program. They came for the harvest season and part of their wages were held for them until they left the country and returned to Mexico. Then a Senator, I believe it was Teddy Kennedy, decided that was cruel and ended the Bracero program and we have never really replaced it.  Withholding wages until they returned to Mexico was a good and should be a part of any future farm labor program. But we should never grant them citizenship . We need to make sure that any guest work program for farm labors compels them to return to their home country at the end of the harvest.

With an economy greater than most nations' in the world, with a very diverse population, with a political leadership that hews primarily to the center and a state budget in balance, California leads by example.  Other areas may have fewer ground faults or a warmer climate year-round but the political climate may be off-putting to the creative types that power technology and other drivers of economic progress.

A big part of what is wrong with our school are the incremental changes that have been made to the curriculum. Today, the Times reported:

"AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas’ State Board of Education has approved new history textbooks, but only after defeating six and seeing a top publisher withdraw a seventh — capping months of outcry over lessons that some academics say exaggerate the influence of Moses in American democracy and negatively portray Muslims.

The board on Friday approved 89 books and classroom software packages that more than five million public school students will begin using next fall. But it took hours of sometimes testy discussion and left publishers scrambling to make hundreds of last-minute edits, some to no avail."

This is only one example of changes that shouldn't be allowed. These students will eventually get to colleges and their font of knowledge will prove to be a handicap and not something they can build on.

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/23/us/texas-approves-disputed-history-tex...

As a Hurricane Sandy refugee, I was taken in by friends who have twin sons who were polishing off their college essays on the vey night I was rescued and and taken in by my friends. These boys were A.P. scholars,whose S.A.T. scores were close to 1600. They had even led their high school team to victory on a T.V. show as the Captain and Co-Captain of a school team of elite students,competing against another such team.
Despite this.their parents, older sister,brother-in-law, and I were enlisted (by the parents,) to vet their college application essays.These boys had written their own essays. This additional scrutiny seemed excessive to me, until I spoke to a friend who lives in Manhattan whose son was rejected from Wharton despite having perfect grades and perfect standardized test scores.I’d heard that there were quotas on students applying to colleges from the Northeast,but had not realized things were this bad.When I suggested to my friend that her daughter’s chances of gaining entry to college would be improved if the parents established residency in Oklahoma (which it would be) my friend responded that her daughter was en route to Oklahoma to build homes.She expressed gratitude that her daughter, unlike her peers,was not traveling to some dangerous area overseas to build homes, in an effort to gain admission to a desirable college.
I can see how such students would be too exhausted and stressed to write multiple essays to submit to multiple colleges.

The education system as a whole needs reform. The universities get our students last. What we do with their education, from the start, is where the problems are.

That writing essays is the impediment is the clue to how far gone we are. Not having to write an essay or writing a shorter one shouldn't be an enticement to anyone who is considering higher education. The reason it is enticing is that public schools should be preparing our kids for college. By the time a young person is accepted at a school, they should have the skills to write a short essay without breaking a sweat. They should also know how to write a decent research paper. All too many high school graduates can't.

As for schools having to massage the number of applicants versus the number of kids who are accepted so they look better in the rankings, what can I say? US News makes an awful lot of money from the rankings racket.

We should invest in our community colleges. For many students, they provide the best preparation for success at a four-year institution. We need to invest in our state schools. Here in California, the UC's are increasing the tuition by an unconscionable 25%. States should make higher education free to residents. In California, people have voted yes to increasing taxes for the purpose of investment in education. I'm willing to bet they'd green-light making state colleges free. Our kids deserve a better future than being saddled with student debt the size of a home mortgage.
Conclusions from incorrect premises are meaningless.

@AACNY: Revisionist history is a wonderful thing, isn't it? It allows one to, in essence, ignore the reality of historical fact and create a fictional history that he/she then presents not only as fact but as justification/validation of his/her present point of view.

Your little swim in the brine of revisionist history takes the form of intimating that the gridlock/obstruction that has marked the 112th and 113th Congresses---and brought our country to its knees in any number of ways---is a congressional "boycott" by which legislators are expressing their indignance per the president's actions in cooperating with various commercial interests---particularly small businesses---to make their transition to the ACA requirements less complicated. Indeed, by-and-large, his actions have been in response to remedies or delays originally suggested by Republican legislators.

However, your assessment of GOP obstruction depends upon all of us agreeing to forget one little item of history: On the night of this president's first Inauguration, the GOP leadership met over dinner and agreed that gridlock/obstruction would be the method they would use to insure he would be a "one-term president."

The GOP's, uh, "boycott" was not born of indignation that the president was acting "imperially." It was born of indignation that he had been elected in the first place.

Historical realities can be a real inconvenience, can't they?

The Senate has ALREADY passed a bipartisan immigration bill the president said he would sign; but Boehner won't even schedule a vote (who's acting like an emperor) cuz he knows it would pass... and the president would sign.
It's all on the Tea Party House and their Speaker Boehner.

"Everything that you do will come back to you."
When Harry Reid passed the "nuclear option" to suspend filibusters on all but SCOTUS nominations, he probably didn't foresee a 54-46 republican senate majority.
When the R's retake the white house someday, perhaps with a democratic congress, the president will cite Obama as he legislates new law from the oval office, "until congress sends me a bill I can sign."
Constitutions and separations of power are vexing to any chief executive, but the alternative is far worse: the rule of law supplanted by the whim of the supreme leader.

Let's keep in mind that even the name "Federal Reserve" is misleading. It is a private banking organization that skims money off the top of the economy while adding no value whatsoever.
Someday the charade will collapse upon it's own greed and we'll wonder how could we have been so dumb for so long.

The oxymoronic pairing of "Cheney" and "liberalism" in the last sentence is all the proof we need that this column is a spoof. Even Douthat can't keep up the charade of taking himself seriously, indulging in such of false equivalence slapstick.

Maybe Obama's predecessor was able to pass such atrocities as No Child Left Behind, Medicare Drug Coverage to benefit Big Pharma, funding two misbegotten wars, gifting the rich with ridiculous tax cuts, etc. -- but he did so with a combination of shameless fear-mongering post 9/11, plus the "nuclear option" of ramming through various pieces of legislation without the benefit of the horrendous super-majority requirement, and most effective of all,twangy down-home mendacity. Bush was smart only insofar that he never made the mistake of negotiating out loud with himself. He relied on his gut. And look where that got us.

Obama's other big mistake was that in failing to hold Bush and his cadre of war and financial criminals accountable, he became instantly complicit. And being only human, he can't be expected to voluntarily relinquish the unitary executive powers bequeathed to him by the Dishonorable Dick.

Funny how Douthat only moans about Obama killing people now that Obama has issued a pretty innocuous immigration relief directive. Where was he then, or when Bush legalized torture and when Cheney was handing out billions of dollars in no-bid Iraq occupation contracts to his cronies?

Missing in action, just like his latest column.

His party has lost 2 consecutive mid-terms and he was implored by his party's candidates to not make this move before this mid-term because it would hurt them.

Whichever constituents you are talking about, there were not enough of them to make a significant showing.

Hi AACNY,
The Representatives and Senators who lost this month did so on their own records and tepid campaigning. Many felt comfortable attributing their own poor showing to him, but that's a cop-out.
Thank you for taking the time to reply to my post. Best regards.
We "lost" the 2012 midterm with 10 million more votes than the Republicans so you might want to rethink that. We lost the house with 500,000 more votes than the republicans because of gerrymandering.

President Obama is no Emperor.  He does answer - to constituents, who re-elected him with four percentage points of the popular vote and an approval rating 3x that of Congress.  It is the legislative branch who fancy themselves un beholden to actual governance.

ed connor camp springs, md:

"until congress sends me a bill I can sign."

***
That would actually be progress. Now, the president actively blocks the parts of the laws with which he disagrees or in this case, creates his own, and Congress has boycotted sending him any new laws.

If we could get the president to do his job and commit to either execute it as written or veto it, we might actually get this Congress to pass something.

I've read a 31 page memo related to the memo that Obama relied upon. http://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R42924.pdf
It concludes that prosecutorial discretion is normally enforced on a case-by-case basis and it is by no means clear that such discretion covers a blanket order affecting millions at once. You're right -- Obama is acting on sound legal advice. But the advice indicates he probably has no authority to do what he's done.
Don't be so sure that a lot of Republicans aren't howling Impeachment! There seems to be a pretty solid constitutional basis for doing so.

President Obama is exercising prosecutorial discretion based on sound legal advice from his team. George Bush, on the other hand, was just plain indiscreet. If he'd possessed even a smidgen of discretionary thinking abilities, he never would have invaded and occupied Iraq. If the Republican Party itself possessed even a smidgen of a moral compass, it never would have nominated Bush for the highest office in the land, nor allowed Dick Cheney to crown himself Viceroy of the American Imperium.

If Ross Douthat wants to complain about Obama's exercise of prosecutorial discretion, perhaps he should devote a future column to how this privilege has heretofore only benefited the rich and powerful. To CIA torturers and to Wall Street bankers, Obama turns a wilfully blind prosecutorial eye and the Republicans offer nary a blink in response. But the minute Obama grants a modicum of relief to the poor and downtrodden (and Latino) the Republicans all indulge in an infantile group temper tantrum. Why are the Republicans not howling impeachment! or imperial presidency! over these transgressions? Why do I even have to ask that question?

It's the hypocrisy, stupid.

Great movie. How could you not love it?

When we went to Pearl Harbor, Elaine told Alex and me to pretend she was Filipina. She was kidding. I think.
Martin, the wife is really into From Her to Eternity.  Apparently you are not.

Making something doesn't create a demand for it.  That is not Say's law.  Say contended that growing something, say wheat in Iowa, creates a demand for something else, say cars from Japan.  The amount of demand created is determined by how highly Japanese car makers value the wheat that I have grown. Thus, in your example of lead baseballs which I'm assuming are useless, very little or no demand would be created.  The market functions to reward those who avoid making such mal-investments like the person who chooses to build a lead baseball factory over some more useful industry by making the wheat grower earn a profit and forcing the lead baseball producer to take a loss if he can make a sale at all.

Why on earth would you think that they wouldn't?  You will recall that despite years of bleating about "repeal and replace," the Republicans have yet to come up with even a laughable alternative. And, even though the Democrats miserably failed to remind the public, the Republicans celebrated Christmas last year by expanding farm subsidies for themselves and their favored constituents while cutting food support for over 2 million Americans who don't happen to own farms.  (For Jesus' view of people who are indifferent to other people's suffering, please see Matthew 25:42 ff.)

Mark,

At least 2/3 of them still are uncovered!

You've forgotten Republicans incredible ability to believe that facts--and reality--have a liberal bias, so they just make stuff up as they go along.  They simply ignore the question of uninsured Americans and concentrate on fear--one of their favorite emotions--of socialized medicine, whatever the heck that means.
50 million Americans were without healthcare coverage before the ACA. I can't really believe the republicans would want to go back to that.
That is why I never read Douthat's columns, only the comments.

The very phrase "self-admiring willingness to incorporate conservative ideas" tells you that no matter what President Obama does, Douthat will castigate him for it.

It's clearly not about policy, it's about something Douthat does not want to state clearly.

Only 32 comments at the time I write this and there's already strong confirmation of something becomes more obvious with each of Douthat's columns: if being in touch with reality were a criterion for what it takes to be an op-ed writer for the NYT, there are at least 32 of us readers who are more qualified.

There's nothing wrong with being an ideologue, but Douthat can't, or won't, make any kind of factual or intellectual case for his ideology. If the purpose of comments such as these were some kind of dialogue with the columnist, we would probably be wasting our time with Douthat. It's clear that while he has everything to learn from his readers, he in fact learns nothing.

With a little more effort Douthat could have written a good column with some explanatory power. Instead we get:

"...he has chosen to betray himself in a different way..."

We all "get" that as the president moves through his term he encounters realities requiring action that are inconsistent with prior publicly expressed positions. Voters expect this from leaders. A more important question is does the president's actions meet the demands of the day? We're not scoring a debate; we're moving into a difficult future.

With regard to immigration, what has gone unremarked is the emerging realization that neither the Senate nor the House, in either the lame duck session or the new session commencing in January, is likely to take a floor vote on an immigration bill.

So, what has the president done besides tackling an urgent issue? He has teed up immigration as a major campaign issue for the 2016 presidential election. Yes, one can understand the Republicans' angry frustration; they do not want to deal with the issue now, next year, or in 2016. They are making a powerful statement about their party's ability "to lead."

I completely agree with Douhat on this one: President Obama is to liberalism as Cheney is to conservatism. Liberalism standing for social inclusion, compassion and opportunities for all and conservatism standing for every man for himself, free market principles and white privilege.

As much as he was criticized for his 2006 World Cup performance, Landon Donovan has been criticized even more for not fully testing himself in the top-flight European leagues after washing out with Bayer Leverkusen. A couple successful loan stints with Everton in the English Premier League only make the critics ask why he didn't challenge himself further in Europe.

But by staying home and playing in MLS, he took on a greater challenge, making soccer a relevant part of the American sports landscape. Now that the league is booming and the US Men's National Team drew better TV ratings at the 2014 World Cup than the NBA Finals and the World Series did, it's clear that Donovan made the right decision, both for himself and for American soccer.

Our domestic league and our domestic talent still have a ways to go, but it's hard to see how they get there without the foundation laid so far by the greatest player in American men's soccer history.

It'll be a long time before we have another player with his talent put on the red white and blue. His career was one of a kind. He could've made so much more money sitting on high-profile European benches, but instead he stayed close to home and did more to help his domestic league grow than nearly anyone. He sounds happy. And as a US Soccer fan, all I can do is offer my thanks and wish him well.

What intellectual?  That someone has grammar and vocabulary does not make one an intellectual.  One has to actually be able to reason critically to be an intellectual, in fact, to even demonstrate a useful mind.

At the same time, he has been much more aggressive than Bush in his use of executive power to pursue major domestic policy goals — on education, climate change, health care and now most sweepingly on immigration.

Another graph in the Times showed he used executive orders less than any President Grover Cleveland, but Ross only includes education, health care, climate change and immigration.

http://tinyurl.com/qfh7lou

Nice try, but disingenous. Especially for such an intellectual.

"[Republicans] only incentive is to obstruct, wreck, and sabotage."

You forgot whine: Republicans have taken whining and casting themselves as "victims" to heights (lows) never before seen.

At least they don't have Benghazi to whine about any longer.

"It isn’t just that he’s been dealing with an opposition party that’s swung to the right; it’s that this opposition doesn’t know its own mind, collectively or sometimes even individually, and so has trouble bargaining or legislating effectively."

But the opposition does know its mind. What it has done has been deliberate. It has no incentive to work with a Democratic president on anything. So it doesn't. Its only incentive is to obstruct, wreck, and sabotage. The fact that it has been so successful, implies far more negative implications for the future of the Presidency than what Obama just did.

But you know that. This is the recurring theme in all your columns. Whenever your party does something harmful, it is always just poor tactics or disorganization or something that can changed with just a little rethinking. But this problem is one of your party's INTENT and of its CHARACTER. That is not so easily fixed.
McConnell: "I want to make Obama a one term President." Obama thought: In my second term I want to have a big impact. I side with Obama.
Name calling is art form Republicans learned from democrats. After discovering that if used adroitly it can work. Thank you, Mr. Alinsky.

When will the shameless Republican name calling end?

All of the Republican name calling for the past six years has been a smokescreen for the Republican's failure of leadership, failure to govern, failure to legislate and failure to do anything for the majority of Americans.

Nothing in recent history can compare to the "Imperialistic" co-presidents Bush/Cheney as they perpetrated a lie to start the Iraq War, caused the needless death of thousands of American soldiers, caused the wounding of ten of thousands more American soldiers, causing the complete destabilizing of the delicate balance in the Middle-East region and only succeeded in helping to enable their Wall Street and "too big to fail" banker buddies to nearly collapse the American and world enconomies!

Soon with control of both the Senate and the House the Republican's will be forced to put up or shut up. Let's see whose interests the Republican's really care about.

It's time for the name calling to end and let's instead talk about the real and many problems that confront our nation.

Interestingly, up until the 13 century, the Islamic Empire led the world in math, science, technology, and the humanities. The Empire fell in the 13 century after conservative elements banned all progressive institutions but the military, presumably knowing that they needed that to protect themselves.

Western civilization, through Europe, inherited the advanced Islam math, science, and technology and went on to fully emerge from the 'dark ages' and grow to lead and rule the world.............until now, when conservative elements are seeking to ban all math, science, and technology other than the military in order to implement a more rigorous form of social discipline.

For myself the United States of America ended August 3, 1980 when Ronald Wilson Reagan started his presidential campaign in Philadelphia Mississippi praising the mob that lynched Chaney, Goodman and Schwerner. Yes there were the occasional heartbeats but never again would the United States America be a nation that led the Western democracies into the 21st century.
The wealth and military power would continue but the six year attack on a president who twice won office playing by the rules seems a clear indication that the mightiest nation that has ever existed is dysfunctional both within and outside its border.
Today's story about Texas history books certainly echoes the prophetic words of George Orwell's 1984. Many of us were alive when Ronald Wilson Reagan proved his paucity of courage when as head of the Screen Actors Guild he went before the House UnAmerican Activities Committee and the head of the FBI and proceeded to name names of his guild members who were engaged in a nonexistent plot to subvert the US government. Tomorrow Texas history books will demand Reagan's face on Mount Rushmore.
The claim of President Obama wanting to become an Imperial president is simply absurd when his white hair clearly indicates the Empire and certainly the country's main concern is survival not empire.

His party has lost 2 consecutive mid-terms and he was implored by his party's candidates to not make this move before this mid-term because it would hurt them.

Whichever constituents you are talking about, there were not enough of them to make a significant showing.
